GEOGRAPHY AND DMA PLANNING FRAMEWORK v5.5

VERSION 5.5
DATE January 2026
STATUS Production Ready
DOCUMENT TYPE Knowledge Base - Step 4 Geography Planning

This document defines the requirements for Geography planning in Step 4 of the media plan development process. Geography planning establishes WHERE the campaign will run and provides the foundation for budget allocation and outcome projections by market.

Geography is not just a targeting input - it is an analytical framework. Every geography decision must be justified with population data, target audience sizing, and projected outcomes. The agent must always present geography selections in structured table format with rollup calculations.

The agent supports four levels of geographic granularity based on campaign sophistication and targeting requirements.

LEVEL 1 COUNTRY
- Simplest level for national campaigns
- Single row plus total
- Used when no geographic variation in strategy

LEVEL 2 DMA
- Designated Market Area level
- Standard for most campaigns
- 210 DMAs in United States
- Rolls up to Country total

LEVEL 3 DMA PLUS CORRIDOR
- DMA level with corridor subdivisions
- Corridors are named geographic clusters within DMAs
- Example Los Angeles DMA might have corridors for Downtown, Westside, Valley, South Bay
- Each corridor rolls up to its parent DMA
- DMAs roll up to Country total

LEVEL 4 ZIP CODES
- Most granular level
- ZIP codes roll up to parent DMA
- DMAs roll up to Country total
- Used for hyperlocal campaigns or when first-party data enables ZIP-level precision

The agent MUST present geography selections in table format. The table structure varies based on granularity level but always includes these core columns.

PHASE 1 COLUMNS - GEOGRAPHY DEFINITION
Present these columns when Step 4 Geography is being defined, before channel and budget allocation.

- Geography Name - The DMA name, corridor name, or ZIP code
- Parent Geography - The parent level for rollup (DMA for ZIPs, Country for DMAs)
- Total Population - Total population in that geography area
- Target Audience Size - Population after demographic, behavioral, and contextual signal filters
- Target Audience Percent - Target audience as percentage of total population

PHASE 2 COLUMNS - POST BUDGET AND CHANNEL ALLOCATION
Add these columns once Step 5 Budget and Step 7 Channels are complete.

- Planned Media Spend - Total planned spend for that geography
- Spend Per Target - Planned spend divided by target audience size
- Projected Impressions - Expected impressions for that geography
- Projected Clicks - Expected clicks for that geography
- Projected Conversions - Expected conversions for that geography
- Projected CAC or CPA - Cost per acquisition for that geography

For ZIP-level tables:
- Subtotal row after each DMA grouping showing sum of ZIPs in that DMA
- Grand total row at bottom showing national totals

For DMA-level tables:
- Grand total row at bottom showing national totals

For DMA plus Corridor tables:
- Subtotal row after each DMA grouping showing sum of corridors in that DMA
- Grand total row at bottom showing national totals
sectionTitle: ROLLUP AND SUBTOTAL REQUIREMENTS MANDATORY ROLLUP RULES

content:
These columns use SUM aggregation:
- Total Population
- Target Audience Size
- Planned Media Spend
- Projected Impressions
- Projected Clicks
- Projected Conversions

These columns use WEIGHTED AVERAGE aggregation:
- Target Audience Percent - weighted by total population
- Spend Per Target - weighted by target audience size
- Projected CAC or CPA - weighted by projected conversions
sectionTitle: CALCULATION RULES FOR SUBTOTALS AND TOTALS

content:
EXAMPLE 1 - DMA LEVEL TABLE PHASE 1

| DMA | Total Population | Target Audience | Target Pct |
| New York NY | 20,100,000 | 1,206,000 | 6.0% |
| Los Angeles CA | 13,200,000 | 924,000 | 7.0% |
| Chicago IL | 9,500,000 | 570,000 | 6.0% |
| Houston TX | 7,200,000 | 504,000 | 7.0% |
| Phoenix AZ | 4,900,000 | 343,000 | 7.0% |
| TOTAL | 54,900,000 | 3,547,000 | 6.5% |

Note the TOTAL row Target Pct of 6.5 percent is the weighted average, not simple average of the percentages.

EXAMPLE 2 - DMA LEVEL TABLE PHASE 2 WITH BUDGET AND OUTCOMES

| DMA | Population | Target Aud | Tgt Pct | Spend | Spend Per Tgt | Proj Conv | Proj CAC |
| New York NY | 20,100,000 | 1,206,000 | 6.0% | $85,000 | $0.070 | 850 | $100.00 |
| Los Angeles CA | 13,200,000 | 924,000 | 7.0% | $65,000 | $0.070 | 650 | $100.00 |
| Chicago IL | 9,500,000 | 570,000 | 6.0% | $45,000 | $0.079 | 400 | $112.50 |
| Houston TX | 7,200,000 | 504,000 | 7.0% | $35,000 | $0.069 | 350 | $100.00 |
| Phoenix AZ | 4,900,000 | 343,000 | 7.0% | $20,000 | $0.058 | 175 | $114.29 |
| TOTAL | 54,900,000 | 3,547,000 | 6.5% | $250,000 | $0.070 | 2,425 | $103.09 |

Note TOTAL row Proj CAC of $103.09 is weighted average by conversions, not simple average.

EXAMPLE 3 - DMA PLUS CORRIDOR TABLE

| DMA | Corridor | Population | Target Aud | Tgt Pct | Spend | Proj Conv |
| Los Angeles CA | Downtown | 2,500,000 | 200,000 | 8.0% | $20,000 | 200 |
| Los Angeles CA | Westside | 1,800,000 | 162,000 | 9.0% | $18,000 | 180 |
| Los Angeles CA | Valley | 3,200,000 | 224,000 | 7.0% | $15,000 | 150 |
| Los Angeles CA | South Bay | 2,100,000 | 147,000 | 7.0% | $12,000 | 120 |
| LA SUBTOTAL | | 9,600,000 | 733,000 | 7.6% | $65,000 | 650 |
| San Diego CA | Central | 1,400,000 | 98,000 | 7.0% | $8,000 | 80 |
| San Diego CA | North County | 900,000 | 72,000 | 8.0% | $7,000 | 70 |
| SD SUBTOTAL | | 2,300,000 | 170,000 | 7.4% | $15,000 | 150 |
| GRAND TOTAL | | 11,900,000 | 903,000 | 7.6% | $80,000 | 800 |
The target audience size must account for all targeting signals applied to the campaign.

Demographic Signals
- Age range
- Gender
- Household income
- Education level
- Homeownership status
- Presence of children

Behavioral Signals
- In-market purchase intent
- Content consumption patterns
- Past purchase history
- Site visitation behavior
- App usage patterns
- Search behavior

Contextual Signals
- Daypart targeting
- Device targeting
- Content category alignment
- Weather-based triggers
- Location-based triggers

Start with total population for the geography.
Apply each signal as a filter to reduce the addressable population.
The resulting number is the target audience size.

Example calculation:
- Los Angeles DMA total population 13,200,000
- Age 25 to 54 reduces to 5,280,000 (40 percent of population)
- HHI over 75K reduces to 2,640,000 (50 percent of age-qualified)
- In-market for financial services reduces to 924,000 (35 percent of income-qualified)
- Target audience is 924,000 which is 7.0 percent of total population

The agent should explain the audience sizing logic when presenting the geography table.

- US Census Bureau American Community Survey
- Nielsen DMA definitions and population estimates
- Platform-specific reach estimates from Meta, Google, TTD
sectionTitle: DATA SOURCES FOR POPULATION AND AUDIENCE SIZING POPULATION DATA SOURCES

content:
- Platform planning tools (Meta Ads Manager, Google Keyword Planner)
- Third-party data providers (Experian, Acxiom, LiveRamp)
- First-party data from client CRM or CDP
- KB benchmark data for typical audience penetration by vertical

When presenting the table, cite the data source used for population and audience estimates.

The agent MUST NOT proceed from Step 4 to Step 5 (Budget) until audience is SIZED per
geography. This is a hard gate. No exceptions unless user explicitly overrides.

WRONG BEHAVIOR - INCOMPLETE:
"Great, you want to focus on Los Angeles, Houston, and Chicago DMAs. Let's move to
budget allocation."

RIGHT BEHAVIOR - COMPLETE:
"Based on your targeting signals, here is your audience sizing by DMA:"

| DMA | Total Population | Target Audience | Target % |
|-----|------------------|-----------------|----------|
| Los Angeles | 13,200,000 | 924,000 | 7.0% |
| Houston | 7,200,000 | 504,000 | 7.0% |
| Chicago | 9,500,000 | 570,000 | 6.0% |
| TOTAL | 29,900,000 | 1,998,000 | 6.7% |

"Your total addressable audience is 2.0M across these three DMAs. At your $400K budget
and 5,000 customer target, you are projecting $80 CAC with 0.25% conversion rate from
target audience. This is achievable with standard targeting. Shall we proceed to budget
allocation?"

WHY THIS MATTERS:
- Budget allocation without audience sizing is arbitrary
- Cannot calculate budget-per-target-customer without sizing
- Cannot assess targeting precision without knowing audience penetration
- Plans without sizing fail in-market due to misallocated spend

SIZING DATA SOURCES:
- Platform tools (Meta Ads Manager, Google Keyword Planner) for reach estimates
- Census ACS data for demographic filters
- KB benchmarks for vertical-typical penetration rates
- State assumption clearly if using estimates

WHEN ENTERING STEP 4 GEOGRAPHY

1. Ask about geographic scope - national, regional, or local
2. Ask about granularity needed - DMA, corridor, or ZIP level
3. Present initial geography table with Phase 1 columns INCLUDING AUDIENCE SIZE
4. Get user confirmation or refinement of geography selections
5. DO NOT proceed to Step 5 until audience is SIZED per geography

WHEN STEP 5 BUDGET IS COMPLETE

1. Update geography table with planned spend allocation by geography

3. Highlight any geographies with significantly higher or lower spend per target

WHEN STEP 7 CHANNELS IS COMPLETE

1. Update geography table with projected outcomes by geography
sectionTitle: 2. Calculate spend per target for each geography

content:
3. Highlight any geographies with projected efficiency significantly different from average
4. Provide recommendation if budget reallocation between geographies would improve overall efficiency
sectionTitle: 2. Calculate projected CAC or CPA for each geography

content:
Always use consistent column headers across all geography tables in the session.
Always include subtotal rows at every major hierarchy break.
Always include grand total row at the bottom.
Use weighted averages for percentage and efficiency metrics in subtotal and total rows.
Use sum aggregation for absolute count metrics in subtotal and total rows.
Round population and audience numbers to nearest thousand for DMA level.
Round population and audience numbers to nearest hundred for ZIP level.
Round spend to nearest dollar.
Round percentages to one decimal place.
Round CAC and CPA to two decimal places.

Geography table informs and is informed by other steps.

Step 3 Audience - Target audience definition determines the filters applied to size the target audience in each geography.

Step 5 Budget - Budget allocation by geography must sum to total campaign budget. Geography table shows how budget is distributed.

Step 7 Channels - Channel mix may vary by geography. Some channels have limited inventory in certain DMAs. The projected outcomes in geography table must align with channel projections.

Step 8 Measurement - Some measurement approaches work better in specific geographies. Geo-holdout testing requires clean geography definition.

The agent must flag these error conditions.

Total budget in geography table does not equal campaign budget - Flag mismatch and reconcile.

Projected conversions by geography do not sum to total projected conversions - Recalculate and align.

Target audience size exceeds total population for any geography - Data error, investigate source.

Any geography has zero planned spend but is included in table - Either allocate spend or remove from table.

Spend per target varies more than 50 percent across geographies - Highlight and ask user if intentional.

VERSION: 5.5
EFFECTIVE DATE - JANUARY 2026
DOCUMENT TYPE - KNOWLEDGE BASE IMPLICATION CHAIN
COMPLIANCE - 6-RULE COMPLIANT

================================================================================

This document provides comprehensive implication mapping for audience targeting decisions. The agent MUST consult this document when users define audience strategies, targeting parameters, or segmentation approaches. Expert advisors never simply execute targeting decisions without helping clients understand how audience choices affect reach, efficiency, and long-term customer acquisition.

This document covers implication chains for:
- Audience size decisions
- Targeting precision trade-offs
- First-party versus third-party data strategies
- Lookalike and expansion strategies
- Audience exclusion decisions
- Retargeting pool management

================================================================================

When targeting highly specific audiences:
- Week 1-2: Rapid audience saturation possible
- Week 3-4: Frequency escalates quickly within small pool
- Week 5-8: Creative fatigue accelerates due to repeated exposure
- Month 2-3: Audience exhaustion limits scale
- Long-term: Efficiency may decline as addressable market depletes

When targeting moderately sized audiences:
- Week 1-2: Balanced reach and frequency build
- Week 3-4: Optimization identifies high-value segments
- Week 5-8: Sustainable pacing without rapid exhaustion
- Month 2-3: Room for audience expansion based on learnings
- Long-term: Sufficient scale for ongoing optimization

When targeting large audiences:
- Week 1-2: Slow frequency build across large pool
- Week 3-4: Algorithm optimization surfaces high performers
- Week 5-8: Waste inherent in broad targeting
- Month 2-3: Strong learnings for future audience refinement
- Long-term: Maximum reach but efficiency trade-offs

When user defines audience size, agent SHOULD ask:
- What is the estimated addressable market for this product or service
- What frequency level is appropriate for this consideration window
- Is scale or precision the higher priority for this campaign
- What expansion strategy exists if primary audience saturates

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 2.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR AUDIENCE SIZE

content:
When applying tight targeting parameters:
- Higher relevance to reached users
- Lower reach within budget
- Higher CPMs due to limited inventory
- Faster audience exhaustion
- Lower waste but potentially missing adjacent opportunities
- Conversion rates typically higher
- Cost per acquisition may be lower or higher depending on competition

When applying loose targeting parameters:
- Lower relevance to many reached users
- Higher reach within budget
- Lower CPMs due to abundant inventory
- Slower audience exhaustion
- Higher waste but captures adjacent opportunities
- Conversion rates typically lower
- Cost per acquisition depends on waste level

When applying multiple targeting criteria:
- Each layer reduces addressable audience
- Combined layers create very narrow pools
- Inventory availability decreases with each layer
- CPMs increase with targeting complexity
- Risk of over-engineering audience
- May exclude valuable prospects who do not match all criteria

When user discusses targeting precision, agent SHOULD ask:
- What evidence supports these specific targeting parameters
- How will you know if precision is too high or too low
- What is the trade-off tolerance between reach and relevance
- Are there audience signals you may be missing with tight targeting

================================================================================

When using customer file matching:
- Match rates vary by platform (40-80 percent typical)
- Audience skews toward known, existing relationships
- Limited prospecting value for new customer acquisition
- Strong for retention and cross-sell campaigns
- Privacy-safe but requires data infrastructure
- Excludes prospects who could become valuable customers

When retargeting website visitors:
- Audience limited to those who have visited
- Strong intent signal for most visitors
- Pool size depends on traffic volume
- Recency windows affect pool size and relevance
- 7-day pools show highest intent, 30-day pools provide scale
- Pool health requires ongoing prospecting investment

When integrating CRM data for targeting:
- Enables lifecycle-based targeting
- Requires data synchronization infrastructure
- Customer stage influences messaging relevance
- Suppression of existing customers possible
- Enables true customer acquisition measurement
- Data freshness critical for accuracy

When user discusses first-party data strategy, agent SHOULD ask:
- What first-party data assets are available and activated
- What is the match rate expectation for customer files
- How frequently is first-party data refreshed
- What prospecting strategy complements first-party targeting

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 4.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR FIRST-PARTY DATA

content:
When using demographic data for targeting:
- Age and gender targeting widely available
- Accuracy varies by platform and data source
- Income and education data less reliable
- Household composition available on some platforms
- Reduces reach but improves relevance
- May exclude valuable prospects outside demographic assumptions

When using behavioral data for targeting:
- Interest signals based on browsing and content consumption
- In-market signals indicate active consideration
- Purchase behavior from data partners
- Data freshness varies significantly
- Strong relevance when data is accurate
- Privacy regulations limiting availability

When using contextual targeting:
- Based on content being consumed, not user identity
- Privacy-safe as no personal data required
- Relevance depends on content-product fit
- Inventory availability varies by context
- Less precise than behavioral but more privacy-compliant
- Growing importance as third-party cookies decline

When user discusses third-party data strategy, agent SHOULD ask:
- What third-party data sources are being considered
- How has data accuracy been validated
- What is the privacy compliance status of data sources
- How will you measure third-party data effectiveness

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 5.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR THIRD-PARTY DATA

content:
When creating lookalike audiences:
- Seed audience quality determines lookalike quality
- Expansion percentage affects precision and scale
- 1-2 percent lookalikes most similar to seed
- 5-10 percent lookalikes provide scale with less precision
- Performance typically declines as expansion increases
- Requires sufficient seed size (typically 1,000+ users)

When using platform audience expansion:
- Algorithm identifies users beyond defined audience
- Control over expansion varies by platform
- May reach users outside intended targeting
- Can discover valuable segments not anticipated
- Requires monitoring for audience drift
- Trade-off between algorithm learning and targeting control

When balancing prospecting and retargeting:
- Heavy retargeting depletes pools without replenishment
- Heavy prospecting builds pools but lower immediate efficiency
- Typical healthy ratio is 60-70 percent prospecting, 30-40 percent retargeting
- Ratio varies by funnel stage and campaign objective
- Pool health metrics indicate ratio adjustment needs
- Incrementality differs significantly between prospecting and retargeting

When user discusses lookalike or expansion strategy, agent SHOULD ask:
- What is the seed audience for lookalike creation
- What expansion percentage balances scale and precision needs
- How will you monitor for audience drift with expansion
- What is the current prospecting to retargeting ratio

================================================================================

When excluding existing customers:
- Enables true new customer acquisition measurement
- Reduces waste spending on already-converted users
- May miss cross-sell and upsell opportunities
- Requires customer file integration and matching
- Match rate limitations mean some customers still reached
- Consider separate campaigns for retention versus acquisition

When excluding recent converters:
- Prevents annoying users with offers for already-purchased items
- Reduces waste on low-propensity users
- Exclusion window affects pool size
- 7-day exclusion prevents immediate annoyance
- 30-day exclusion for consideration products
- 90-day exclusion for durable goods

When excluding specific audience segments:
- Reduces waste on low-value segments
- May exclude some potential converters incorrectly
- Requires ongoing validation of exclusion effectiveness
- Platform limitations on exclusion implementation
- Consider suppression versus exclusion approaches
- Brand safety exclusions differ from performance exclusions

When user discusses audience exclusions, agent SHOULD ask:
- What data enables exclusion implementation
- What is the match rate for exclusion audiences
- How will you validate exclusions are working correctly
- Are there segments being excluded that should be reconsidered

================================================================================

Healthy retargeting pools require:
- Consistent traffic from prospecting investment
- Reasonable recency windows for intent relevance
- Sufficient size for campaign scale requirements
- Diversity of entry points and behaviors
- Regular refresh through new visitor acquisition
- Monitoring of conversion rate trends within pools

When retargeting pools shrink:
- Frequency increases for remaining pool members
- Performance typically declines as easy conversions complete
- CPMs may decrease due to smaller audience
- Incrementality declines as you reach the same users repeatedly
- Prospecting investment needed to rebuild
- Consider expanding recency windows temporarily

When segmenting retargeting pools:
- Higher-intent segments warrant higher investment
- Product page visitors outperform homepage visitors
- Cart abandoners show highest purchase intent
- Recency segments have different value
- Requires sufficient pool size for segmentation
- Testing needed to validate segment value differences

When user discusses retargeting pools, agent SHOULD ask:
- What is current pool size and trend direction
- What recency windows are being used
- How is prospecting investment supporting pool health
- What segmentation exists within retargeting pools

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 8.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR POOL MANAGEMENT

content:
User scenario: We want to target only CFOs at companies with 500+ employees in the manufacturing sector.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Audience size: Estimated 50,000-100,000 individuals nationally
- Week 1-2: Rapid saturation of addressable audience
- Week 3-4: Frequency escalates to 10+ per user
- Week 5-8: Audience exhaustion limits continued reach
- Cost implications: CPMs 3-5x higher than broader B2B targeting
- Scale limitations: May not support significant budget

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Validate audience size meets minimum thresholds
- Consider expansion to adjacent titles (VP Finance, Controller)
- Set strict frequency caps to prevent over-exposure
- Plan for audience refresh or expansion mid-campaign
- Set realistic expectations for reach and scale

User scenario: We want to target in-market auto intenders from a data partner.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Data accuracy: In-market signals vary in freshness and accuracy
- Privacy status: Third-party data availability declining
- Week 1-2: Initial performance reflects data quality
- Week 3-4: Segment saturation possible for narrow in-market
- Long-term: Consider first-party data strategy development
- Cost implications: Third-party data segments carry premium CPMs

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Test third-party segment against broader targeting
- Measure incrementality of third-party data
- Develop first-party data strategy for long-term sustainability
- Validate data source privacy compliance
- Consider contextual alternatives as backup

User scenario: We want to put 70 percent of budget into retargeting.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: Strong efficiency metrics from high-intent audiences
- Week 3-4: Pool depletion begins if traffic insufficient
- Week 5-8: Incrementality declines as easy conversions complete
- Month 2-3: Pool shrinks without prospecting replenishment
- Long-term: Customer acquisition becomes harder as pools deplete
- Efficiency metrics may mask declining incremental value

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Validate pool size supports 70 percent allocation
- Calculate prospecting needed to maintain pool health
- Consider 50-60 percent retargeting as sustainable maximum
- Implement incrementality testing for retargeting
- Monitor pool size trends weekly

================================================================================

- MPA_Expert_Lens_Audience_Strategy_v5_5_v5_5.txt - Diagnostic patterns for audience decisions
- FIRST_PARTY_DATA_STRATEGY_v5_5.txt - First-party data development
- Analytics_Engine_v5_5.txt - Audience optimization formulas
- MPA_Implications_Channel_Shifts_v5_5_v5_5.txt - Channel-specific audience implications

================================================================================

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the precision intent
- Articulate reach and scale implications
- Explain frequency and fatigue risks
- Recommend expansion contingencies

Example response pattern:
Targeting [narrow audience] provides high relevance but creates scale constraints. Estimated audience of [size] will saturate within [timeframe] at this budget level. Frequency will reach [level] quickly, accelerating creative fatigue. Recommend [expansion option] as contingency and [frequency caps] to manage exposure. What flexibility exists to broaden targeting if performance allows?

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the data approach
- Articulate accuracy and privacy implications
- Explain sustainability considerations
- Recommend validation approach

Example response pattern:
Using [data type] for targeting provides [advantages] but requires [considerations]. Data accuracy varies and privacy regulations are [status]. Recommend testing [data segment] against [control] to validate effectiveness. For long-term sustainability, consider developing [alternative approach]. How will you measure the incremental value of this data?

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the efficiency rationale
- Articulate pool health implications
- Explain incrementality concerns
- Recommend sustainable ratio

Example response pattern:
Allocating [percentage] to retargeting will show strong efficiency metrics but creates pool sustainability concerns. At this ratio, pools will [status] within [timeframe] without sufficient prospecting. Incrementality typically declines as retargeting share increases. Recommend [sustainable ratio] with [prospecting investment] to maintain pool health. What prospecting investment supports this retargeting level?

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 11.3 WHEN USER PROPOSES RETARGETING HEAVY STRATEGY

content:

DOCUMENT TYPE - KNOWLEDGE BASE IMPLICATION CHAIN
COMPLIANCE - 6-RULE COMPLIANT

================================================================================

This document provides comprehensive implication mapping for budget decisions. The agent MUST consult this document when users propose budget changes and MUST articulate second-order and third-order effects before proceeding. Expert advisors never simply execute budget changes without helping clients understand downstream implications.

This document covers implication chains for:
- Total budget increases
- Total budget decreases
- Channel-to-channel reallocations
- Pacing and timing adjustments
- Flexibility allocation decisions

================================================================================

When budget increases, the agent MUST anticipate and communicate:
- Increased impression volume requires creative fatigue monitoring
- Higher spend velocity may trigger platform learning phase resets
- Audience expansion occurs as frequency caps are reached faster
- Competitive dynamics shift as share of voice increases

The agent MUST explain that budget increases typically produce:
- Diminishing returns begin appearing at 120-150 percent of baseline
- Cost per acquisition often rises 10-20 percent before stabilizing
- Incremental reach slows as core audiences saturate
- Cross-channel attribution becomes more complex as touchpoints multiply

The agent MUST help users understand:
- Brand awareness metrics respond with 6-12 week lag
- Customer lifetime value cohorts need 90+ days to validate
- Competitive response typically occurs within 60-90 days
- Market share gains require sustained investment to maintain

When user proposes budget increase, agent SHOULD ask:
- What triggered this increase and is the driver sustainable
- Are current channels already showing diminishing returns signals
- Is creative pipeline sufficient to support increased volume
- What success metrics will validate the increased investment

================================================================================

When budget decreases, the agent MUST articulate:
- Reduced frequency may push below effective threshold
- Platform algorithms may deprioritize campaigns with lower spend
- Audience reach contracts to highest-propensity segments
- Share of voice decreases relative to competitors

The agent MUST explain that budget decreases typically produce:
- Pipeline velocity slows with 4-6 week lag
- Brand awareness metrics begin declining after 8 weeks
- Cost efficiency may temporarily improve as waste is eliminated
- Competitor share of voice increases proportionally

The agent MUST help users understand:
- Demand generation deficit compounds over time
- Customer acquisition costs rise as warm audiences shrink
- Market position becomes harder to regain after extended pullback
- Brand equity erosion accelerates after 3-4 months of reduced presence

When user proposes budget decrease, agent SHOULD ask:
- Is this reduction permanent or temporary with restoration timeline
- Which business objective is being deprioritized
- What monitoring will trigger restoration of funding
- Are there efficiency opportunities before reducing total budget

================================================================================

When reallocating from awareness to conversion channels:
- Short-term efficiency metrics typically improve
- Lead volume may increase for 4-8 weeks
- Demand generation deficit emerges at 8-12 weeks
- Customer acquisition costs rise as warm audiences deplete
- Brand awareness begins declining after 6-8 weeks
sectionTitle: 4.1 UPPER FUNNEL TO LOWER FUNNEL SHIFT

content:
When reallocating from conversion to awareness channels:
- Short-term efficiency metrics typically decline
- Lead volume decreases for 4-8 weeks
- Brand metrics begin improving at 6-12 weeks
- Long-term CAC improvement possible after 3-4 months
- Sales cycle may lengthen during transition
sectionTitle: 4.2 LOWER FUNNEL TO UPPER FUNNEL SHIFT

content:
When reallocating between peer channels:
- Learning phase disruption in both source and destination channels
- Audience overlap effects may be positive or negative
- Platform algorithm resets require 2-3 weeks to stabilize
- Creative requirements may differ significantly
sectionTitle: 4.3 BETWEEN CHANNELS AT SAME FUNNEL STAGE

content:
When user proposes channel reallocation, agent SHOULD ask:
- What performance signal is driving this reallocation
- Have you isolated channel effect from creative or audience effects
- What is the timeline for evaluating the reallocation success
- Is the source channel truly underperforming or facing temporary headwinds

================================================================================

When accelerating spend earlier in campaign period:
- Competitive positioning advantage during high-intent periods
- Risk of creative fatigue before campaign completion
- May exhaust optimal audience segments prematurely
- Limited flexibility for in-flight optimization

When reserving budget for later in campaign period:
- Risk of under-delivery if channels cannot absorb increased spend
- May miss early-period high-intent audiences
- Platform algorithms may favor competitors during light periods
- Provides optimization learning before scaling

When distributing budget evenly across campaign period:
- Balanced reach and frequency throughout flight
- May underinvest during peak opportunity periods
- Predictable performance patterns for forecasting
- Reduced risk of delivery issues

When user proposes pacing changes, agent SHOULD ask:
- What external event or insight is driving the pacing preference
- How will you know if the chosen pacing strategy is working
- What flexibility do you want to preserve for optimization
- Are there seasonal or competitive factors to consider

================================================================================

When holding significant budget in reserve:
- Maximum optimization opportunity during flight
- Lower initial reach and frequency
- Competitive disadvantage during campaign launch
- Requires robust in-flight decision framework

When committing most budget upfront:
- Maximum initial reach and frequency
- Limited ability to respond to performance signals
- Reduced optimization opportunity
- Higher risk if initial strategy underperforms

When discussing flexibility allocation, agent SHOULD ask:
- How confident are you in the initial channel and audience strategy
- What decision rights exist for in-flight reallocation
- How frequently will performance be reviewed
- What performance thresholds would trigger reallocation

================================================================================

User scenario: We want to increase Q2 budget from 500K to 650K.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: Platform learning phases reset, CPMs may spike temporarily
- Week 3-4: Incremental reach slows as we exhaust core audience segments
- Week 5-8: Diminishing returns appear, CPA rises 15-25 percent versus baseline
- Month 2-3: Brand awareness responds, consideration metrics improve
- Month 3-6: If sustained, market share gains become measurable

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Phase the increase over 3-4 weeks to limit learning phase disruption
- Increase creative pipeline to support higher volume
- Set expectation that CPA efficiency will temporarily decline
- Define success metrics for the incremental investment

User scenario: We need to reduce Q2 budget from 500K to 375K.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: Reach and frequency decline proportionally
- Week 3-4: Short-term efficiency may appear to improve
- Week 5-8: Pipeline velocity slows as demand generation reduces
- Month 2-3: Brand awareness begins declining
- Month 3-6: Customer acquisition costs rise as warm audiences deplete

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Prioritize highest-performing channels rather than reducing all proportionally
- Cut channels below minimum viable thresholds entirely
- Shift budget to lower-funnel channels only if short-term efficiency is priority
- Set realistic expectations for reduced goal achievement

User scenario: Move 100K from Display to Paid Social.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: Display reach and frequency decline, Social enters learning phase
- Week 3-4: Display retargeting pools shrink, Social algorithm optimizes
- Week 5-8: Cross-channel attribution shifts as path to conversion changes
- Month 2-3: Full effect of reallocation becomes measurable
- Month 3-6: Long-term impact on brand awareness if Display was upper-funnel

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Confirm Display underperformance is not creative or audience issue
- Phase the shift over 2-4 weeks to limit disruption
- Monitor Display retargeting pool health during transition
- Set Social performance expectations for learning period

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the opportunity
- Articulate immediate, medium, and long-term implications
- Explain diminishing returns expectations
- Recommend phased approach with monitoring

Example response pattern:
Increasing budget to [amount] creates meaningful opportunity for expanded reach. In the first few weeks, expect platform learning phases to reset and CPMs to temporarily spike. By weeks 3-8, diminishing returns typically emerge with CPA rising 15-25 percent above baseline before stabilizing. Brand awareness metrics respond over 6-12 weeks. Recommend phasing the increase over 3-4 weeks and expanding creative pipeline to support higher volume. What success metrics will validate this investment?

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the constraint
- Articulate immediate, medium, and long-term implications
- Explain demand generation deficit risk
- Recommend prioritization over proportional cuts

Example response pattern:
Reducing budget to [amount] requires careful prioritization. In the first few weeks, reach and frequency decline proportionally. Short-term efficiency may appear to improve. By weeks 5-8, pipeline velocity typically slows as demand generation reduces. Brand awareness begins declining after 8 weeks and customer acquisition costs rise over 3-6 months as warm audiences deplete. Recommend concentrating budget on highest-performing channels and cutting underperformers entirely rather than underfunding all channels. Which channels are most critical to preserve?

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the rationale
- Articulate source and destination channel implications
- Explain cross-channel attribution effects
- Recommend phased transition with monitoring

Example response pattern:
Shifting [amount] from [source] to [destination] will produce immediate and delayed effects. In the first 2 weeks, [source] reach declines while [destination] enters learning phase. By weeks 3-4, [source] audience pools shrink while [destination] algorithm optimizes. Cross-channel attribution shifts over 5-8 weeks as path to conversion changes. Full impact becomes measurable at month 2-3. Recommend phasing the shift over 2-4 weeks to limit disruption. What performance signal is driving this reallocation?

This document provides comprehensive implication mapping for channel mix decisions. The agent MUST consult this document when users propose adding, removing, or significantly adjusting channel allocations. Expert advisors never simply execute channel changes without helping clients understand downstream implications across the entire media ecosystem.

This document covers implication chains for:
- Adding new channels to media mix
- Removing channels from media mix
- Shifting budget between channel tiers
- Changing channel role assignments
- Cross-channel interaction effects

================================================================================

When adding Paid Search to existing mix:
- Immediate: Captures existing demand but does not generate new demand
- Week 2-4: Attribution shifts as search captures credit from upper-funnel channels
- Week 5-8: Brand term bidding becomes competitive consideration
- Month 2-3: Non-brand performance stabilizes after learning phase
- Long-term: Becomes dependent channel requiring ongoing upper-funnel support

When adding Paid Social to existing mix:
- Immediate: Audience targeting requires 2-3 week learning phase
- Week 2-4: Creative performance patterns emerge, fatigue begins
- Week 5-8: Lookalike audiences mature, performance stabilizes
- Month 2-3: Platform algorithm optimization reaches plateau
- Long-term: Requires consistent creative refresh cycle to maintain performance

When adding Programmatic Display to existing mix:
- Immediate: Broad reach at low CPM but limited direct response
- Week 2-4: Retargeting pools begin building from site visitors
- Week 5-8: Viewability and fraud monitoring critical
- Month 2-3: Cross-channel attribution effects become measurable
- Long-term: Contributes to awareness but rarely drives direct conversion

When adding CTV to existing mix:
- Immediate: Premium inventory at higher CPMs than digital
- Week 2-4: Frequency management across platforms challenging
- Week 5-8: Measurement infrastructure requires development
- Month 2-3: Brand awareness lift measurable through surveys
- Long-term: Requires minimum 8-12 week flights for measurable impact

When adding Linear TV to existing mix:
- Immediate: Significant budget commitment with limited targeting
- Week 2-4: Production lead times require 4-8 week planning
- Week 5-8: Reach builds but frequency control limited
- Month 2-3: Brand search volume and direct traffic typically increase
- Long-term: Requires sustained investment for brand building effect

When adding Influencer marketing to existing mix:
- Immediate: Long lead times for creator relationship development
- Week 2-4: Content approval and production cycles variable
- Week 5-8: Engagement patterns differ from traditional channels
- Month 2-3: Attribution challenging due to indirect response path
- Long-term: Audience trust builds over sustained creator relationships

When user proposes adding a channel, agent SHOULD ask:
- What objective does this channel serve that current mix does not address
- What is the minimum viable budget for this channel to be effective
- What measurement approach will validate this channel's contribution
- What internal capabilities exist to manage this channel effectively

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 2.7 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR CHANNEL ADDITION

content:
When any channel is removed from mix:
- Attribution shifts to remaining channels within 1-2 weeks
- Audience touchpoint frequency decreases
- Cross-channel synergy effects diminish
- Competitor share of voice in that channel increases

When removing awareness-focused channels:
- Week 1-4: Lower-funnel efficiency may temporarily appear to improve
- Week 5-8: Demand generation deficit begins emerging
- Month 2-3: Pipeline velocity slows as warm audiences shrink
- Month 4-6: Customer acquisition costs rise significantly
- Long-term: Brand awareness and consideration metrics decline

When removing consideration-focused channels:
- Week 1-4: Upper-funnel to lower-funnel conversion rate declines
- Week 5-8: Sales cycle lengthens as nurturing touchpoints decrease
- Month 2-3: Lead quality may decline without consideration content
- Month 4-6: Lower-funnel channels work harder with less support
- Long-term: Overall marketing efficiency typically declines

When removing conversion-focused channels:
- Week 1-4: Immediate revenue impact measurable
- Week 5-8: Upper-funnel channels appear less efficient due to attribution
- Month 2-3: Conversion rate optimization opportunities lost
- Month 4-6: Competitor captures demand you generated
- Long-term: Return on upper-funnel investment harder to demonstrate

When user proposes removing a channel, agent SHOULD ask:
- What performance data suggests this channel is underperforming
- Have you isolated channel effect from creative, audience, or timing effects
- What happens to the audience this channel was reaching
- How will you measure the impact of this removal on remaining channels

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 3.5 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR CHANNEL REMOVAL

content:
When reallocating from awareness to performance channels:
- Week 1-2: Performance metrics appear to improve immediately
- Week 3-6: Lead volume may increase short-term
- Week 7-12: Demand generation deficit emerges
- Month 3-6: Customer acquisition costs rise as warm audiences deplete
- Month 6+: Brand awareness and consideration metrics decline measurably
sectionTitle: 4.1 SHIFTING FROM AWARENESS TO PERFORMANCE TIER

content:
When reallocating from performance to awareness channels:
- Week 1-2: Performance metrics decline immediately
- Week 3-6: Lead volume decreases, sales pressure increases
- Week 7-12: Brand awareness begins improving
- Month 3-6: Consideration and intent metrics improve
- Month 6+: Performance efficiency typically improves as brand strengthens
sectionTitle: 4.2 SHIFTING FROM PERFORMANCE TO AWARENESS TIER

content:
When adjusting both tiers proportionally:
- Week 1-2: Minimal immediate disruption
- Week 3-6: Cross-channel synergy effects adjust gradually
- Week 7-12: New equilibrium establishes
- Month 3-6: Performance patterns reflect new allocation
- Month 6+: Baseline reestablished for future optimization

When user proposes tier reallocation, agent SHOULD ask:
- What business objective is driving this shift
- What timeline exists for evaluating the tier shift success
- Are stakeholders aligned on expected short-term performance changes
- What monitoring will trigger reversal if results are negative

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 4.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR TIER SHIFTS

content:
When shifting channel focus to retargeting:
- Immediate: Audience pools must be sufficient to support spend
- Week 2-4: Efficiency metrics typically improve
- Week 5-8: Pool depletion risk if prospecting insufficient
- Month 2-3: Incrementality declines as you reach already-interested users
- Long-term: Requires prospecting support to maintain pool health
sectionTitle: 5.1 CHANGING CHANNEL FROM PROSPECTING TO RETARGETING

content:
When shifting channel focus to prospecting:
- Immediate: Efficiency metrics typically decline
- Week 2-4: Learning phase as algorithm finds new audiences
- Week 5-8: Reach expands but conversion rate decreases
- Month 2-3: New audience segments discovered
- Long-term: Builds future retargeting pools and brand awareness
sectionTitle: 5.2 CHANGING CHANNEL FROM RETARGETING TO PROSPECTING

content:
When shifting channel from brand to performance creative:
- Immediate: Conversion metrics typically improve
- Week 2-4: Brand awareness contribution declines
- Week 5-8: Audience response patterns shift
- Month 2-3: Channel becomes optimization-dependent
- Long-term: May reduce overall marketing effectiveness if brand support lost
sectionTitle: 5.3 CHANGING CHANNEL FROM BRAND TO PERFORMANCE FOCUS

content:
When user proposes channel role change, agent SHOULD ask:
- What performance signal suggests the current role is not working
- Are audience pools sufficient to support the new role
- How will this role change affect other channels in the mix
- What metrics will validate the role change success

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 5.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR ROLE CHANGES

content:
Channels that enhance each other when combined:
- TV plus Search: TV drives search volume, search captures demand
- Social plus Display: Social engagement builds retargeting pools for display
- Email plus Paid Media: Email nurtures paid media visitors
- Content plus Search: Content builds organic authority, enhances paid quality score
- Influencer plus Social: Creator content performs in paid social

Channels that may conflict when combined:
- Overlapping retargeting across channels: Frequency overload
- Brand search cannibalization: Paid search capturing organic traffic
- Affiliate plus direct: Attribution conflicts and margin erosion
- Multiple DSPs in programmatic: Bidding against yourself
- Overlapping influencer audiences: Diminishing incremental reach

How channel changes affect attribution:
- Adding channels typically increases path length
- Removing channels concentrates attribution in remaining channels
- Last-click attribution overstates lower-funnel contribution
- Multi-touch attribution reveals true channel interaction value
- Incrementality testing isolates true channel contribution

When evaluating channel interactions, agent SHOULD ask:
- What is the current average path length to conversion
- How much audience overlap exists between channels
- Are you seeing frequency issues across channel combinations
- What attribution model are you using to evaluate channel contribution

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 6.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR INTERACTION EFFECTS

content:
Adding Paid Search:
- Captures existing demand generated by other channels
- Attribution will shift credit from upper-funnel channels
- Brand bidding decisions required within 30-60 days
- Requires ongoing optimization to maintain efficiency

Removing Paid Search:
- Competitors capture demand you generated elsewhere
- Conversion attribution shifts to other lower-funnel channels
- Brand search still occurs but without capture
- Lost ability to control brand messaging in search

Adding Paid Social:
- 2-3 week learning phase before performance stabilizes
- Creative fatigue cycles require ongoing content production
- Audience targeting matures over 4-8 weeks
- Platform dependency increases for first-party data

Removing Paid Social:
- Lose mid-funnel engagement and consideration touchpoints
- Retargeting pool building from social engagement stops
- Competitor presence increases in social feeds
- Influencer amplification opportunities lost

Adding Programmatic Display:
- Broad reach at low cost but limited direct response
- Viewability and fraud monitoring essential
- Retargeting pools build over 4-6 weeks
- Brand safety configuration required

Removing Programmatic Display:
- Awareness reach decreases significantly
- Retargeting pools for other channels shrink
- Competitor display presence increases
- Cross-device tracking capabilities reduced

Adding CTV:
- Premium reach with limited targeting compared to digital
- Frequency management across CTV platforms challenging
- Minimum 8-12 week flights for measurable brand impact
- Measurement requires additional infrastructure

Removing CTV:
- Premium audience reach decreases
- Brand awareness contribution declines
- Competitor CTV presence increases
- Full-funnel attribution path shortens

Adding Linear TV:
- Significant budget commitment with limited targeting
- 4-8 week production and planning lead times
- Reach builds but frequency control limited
- Brand search volume typically increases 2-4 weeks after flight

Removing Linear TV:
- Broad awareness reach declines significantly
- Brand search volume typically decreases
- Competitor TV presence increases
- Requires 8-12 weeks to assess full impact

================================================================================

User scenario: We want to add 75K in CTV to our Q2 plan.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: CTV enters at premium CPMs, frequency management across platforms critical
- Week 3-4: Cross-device matching begins building attribution paths
- Week 5-8: Measurement infrastructure development needed for accurate reporting
- Month 2-3: Brand awareness lift becomes measurable through survey methodology
- Month 3-4: Cross-channel synergy with search and social becomes apparent

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Plan minimum 8-12 week flight for measurable impact
- Establish measurement baseline before launch
- Coordinate creative messaging with existing channels
- Set realistic expectations for attribution complexity
sectionTitle: 8.1 EXAMPLE: ADDING CTV TO EXISTING MIX

content:
User scenario: Display performance is poor, we want to cut it entirely.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: Attribution shifts to remaining channels, especially search and social
- Week 3-4: Retargeting pools for other channels begin shrinking
- Week 5-8: Awareness reach decreases, upper-funnel coverage gaps emerge
- Month 2-3: Other channels may show efficiency decline as warm audience shrinks
- Month 3-4: Competitor display presence increases in your category

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Confirm display underperformance is not creative or targeting issue
- Consider reducing rather than eliminating to preserve retargeting capability
- Monitor other channel efficiency for delayed effects
- Set triggers for restoring display if efficiency decline appears

User scenario: Move 50K from Paid Social to Paid Search.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: Social reach and engagement decline, search captures more demand
- Week 3-4: Social retargeting pools shrink, search efficiency may improve short-term
- Week 5-8: Demand generation from social declines, search may see volume decrease
- Month 2-3: Overall lead volume typically declines as demand generation shrinks
- Month 3-4: Efficiency gains in search plateau as warm audience depletes

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Confirm social underperformance is not creative or audience issue
- Understand that search captures demand but social generates it
- Phase the shift to monitor demand generation impact
- Set realistic expectations for medium-term efficiency changes

================================================================================

sectionTitle: 10.1 WHEN USER PROPOSES ADDING A CHANNEL

content:
Agent MUST:

Example response pattern:

Other channels may see [efficiency changes] as [explanation]. Before complete removal, confirm [channel] underperformance is not [alternative cause]. Consider reducing to [amount] to preserve [capability] while testing impact.
sectionTitle: 10.2 WHEN USER PROPOSES REMOVING A CHANNEL

content:
Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the strategy
- Articulate source and destination channel implications
- Explain cross-channel interaction effects
- Recommend phased approach with monitoring

Example response pattern:
Shifting from [source] to [destination] will affect both channels. [Source] will experience [immediate effects] while [destination] enters learning phase. By weeks 5-8, [cross-channel effects] typically emerge. Recommend phasing over 2-4 weeks to limit disruption and enable course correction. What performance signal is driving this reallocation?

This document provides comprehensive implication mapping for timing and pacing decisions. The agent MUST consult this document when users define campaign timing, pacing strategies, or flight schedules. Expert advisors never simply accept timing decisions without helping clients understand how timing affects performance, competitive dynamics, and measurement.

This document covers implication chains for:
- Campaign flight timing decisions
- Pacing strategy selection
- Seasonal and event-based timing
- Always-on versus flighting strategies
- Launch timing and market entry

================================================================================

When planning short campaign flights:
- Week 1: Learning phase consumes significant portion of flight
- Week 2-3: Optimization limited by insufficient data
- Week 4: Performance stabilizes just as flight ends
- Post-flight: Measurement window too short for accurate attribution
- Long-term: Brand impact minimal, momentum lost between flights

When planning medium campaign flights:
- Week 1-2: Learning phase completes for most channels
- Week 3-4: Optimization adjustments possible with data
- Week 5-6: Performance reaches steady state
- Week 7-8: Creative fatigue may emerge
- Post-flight: Sufficient data for performance analysis

When planning long campaign flights:
- Week 1-2: Learning phase completes
- Week 3-6: Multiple optimization cycles possible
- Week 7-9: Creative refresh likely required
- Week 10+: Audience fatigue and frequency caps critical
- Long-term: Brand awareness builds cumulatively

When user defines flight timing, agent SHOULD ask:
- What objective is this flight designed to achieve
- Does the flight length allow sufficient learning phase
- What creative refresh strategy exists for longer flights
- How will success be measured at flight conclusion

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 2.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR FLIGHT TIMING

content:
When accelerating spend to early flight period:
- Week 1-2: Maximum reach during high-priority period
- Week 3-4: Creative fatigue accelerates
- Week 5-6: Audience exhaustion risk increases
- Week 7-8: Limited budget remaining for optimization
- Long-term: Momentum advantage but flexibility sacrificed

When reserving spend for later flight period:
- Week 1-2: Lower reach and frequency during opening
- Week 3-4: Competitors may gain advantage early
- Week 5-6: Learning phase data informs later optimization
- Week 7-8: Maximum investment with optimization insights
- Long-term: Risk of under-delivery if channels cannot absorb surge

When distributing spend evenly across flight:
- Week 1-2: Consistent reach from campaign start
- Week 3-4: Predictable frequency builds
- Week 5-6: Steady optimization possible throughout
- Week 7-8: Balanced performance throughout flight
- Long-term: No peak impact but sustained presence

When alternating high and low spend periods:
- Week 1-2: High-burst reaches awareness threshold quickly
- Week 3-4: Low period allows audience refresh
- Week 5-6: Second burst rebuilds momentum
- Week 7-8: Pattern continues based on burst schedule
- Long-term: Efficient reach with managed frequency

When user defines pacing strategy, agent SHOULD ask:
- What external events or seasonality drive this pacing preference
- What flexibility exists to adjust pacing in-flight
- Are channels capable of absorbing accelerated spend
- What monitoring will trigger pacing adjustments

================================================================================

When launching during category peak season:
- Competitive intensity highest
- CPMs typically 20-50 percent higher than off-peak
- Consumer intent highest in category
- Share of voice more expensive to maintain
- Conversion rates often higher despite competition

When launching during category low season:
- Competitive intensity lowest
- CPMs typically 20-40 percent lower than peak
- Consumer intent lower in category
- Share of voice easier and cheaper to maintain
- Conversion rates often lower but cost per acquisition may improve

When launching against typical category timing:
- Differentiation opportunity versus competitors
- Consumer attention potentially higher due to less noise
- Brand awareness builds without peak competition
- Purchase intent may require more nurturing
- Long-term brand positioning advantage possible

When user discusses seasonal timing, agent SHOULD ask:
- What is typical competitive behavior during this period
- How does consumer intent vary across your category seasons
- What is budget efficiency priority versus share of voice priority
- Are there category-specific timing considerations

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 4.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR SEASONAL TIMING

content:
When aligning campaigns with major events:
- CPMs spike 30-100 percent during major events
- Consumer attention fragmented across many advertisers
- Creative relevance to event critical for breakthrough
- Measurement complicated by event-related noise
- Competitor activity at maximum during events

When launching before major events:
- Lower CPMs than during-event periods
- Consumer attention building toward event
- Share of voice easier to establish before noise peaks
- Intent may be lower than during-event
- Positioning advantage for event-related messaging

When launching after major events:
- CPMs drop quickly after events conclude
- Consumer attention returns to normal patterns
- Measurement cleaner without event noise
- Competitors may reduce spend creating opportunity
- Intent may decline as urgency fades

When user discusses event-based timing, agent SHOULD ask:
- How relevant is this event to your category and audience
- What is budget tolerance for event-period CPM premiums
- Does creative strategy leverage event context
- What measurement approach accounts for event noise

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 5.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR EVENT TIMING

content:
When maintaining continuous market presence:
- Brand awareness builds cumulatively over time
- Consumer touchpoints consistent throughout purchase journey
- No momentum loss between campaigns
- Steady-state optimization possible
- Higher total investment required for sustained presence
- Less flexibility for peak-period concentration

When running campaigns in distinct flights:
- Budget concentration creates peak impact periods
- Momentum rebuilds each flight
- Learning phase repeated each flight
- Gaps in market presence
- Lower total investment possible
- Maximum flexibility for timing optimization

When combining always-on baseline with burst periods:
- Maintains minimum presence between bursts
- Peak periods get concentrated investment
- Learning phase maintains from baseline
- Balance of reach efficiency and flexibility
- Moderate total investment
- Optimization benefits from continuous data

When user discusses always-on versus flighting, agent SHOULD ask:
- What is the typical customer consideration window in your category
- How quickly does brand awareness decay without advertising
- What is budget availability for sustained versus concentrated investment
- Are there natural peak periods that warrant investment concentration

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 6.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR CONTINUITY STRATEGY

content:
When timing new product launches:
- Week 1-4: Maximum investment builds initial awareness
- Week 5-8: Consideration development requires sustained presence
- Week 9-12: Purchase conversion window depends on category
- Month 3-6: Early adopter feedback influences optimization
- Month 6+: Growth phase requires adjusted strategy

When entering new markets:
- Month 1: Awareness building from zero baseline
- Month 2-3: Competitive response typically emerges
- Month 3-6: Initial market share gains measurable
- Month 6-12: Sustained investment required for position maintenance
- Year 1+: Market position depends on sustained presence

When timing response to competitor actions:
- Week 1-2: Immediate response required for defensive positioning
- Week 3-4: Counter-messaging development and deployment
- Week 5-8: Market share defense assessment
- Month 2-3: Sustained response or strategic pivot decision
- Long-term: Competitive equilibrium reestablished

When user discusses launch timing, agent SHOULD ask:
- What competitive activity is expected during launch window
- How long is the typical consideration window for this product
- What internal readiness exists for launch support
- What measurement will validate launch success timing

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 7.4 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR LAUNCH TIMING

content:
Weekday advertising typically shows:
- Higher B2B engagement Monday through Thursday
- Consumer consideration peaks vary by category
- Friday shows lower engagement for complex decisions
- CPMs often lower on weekends for many categories
- Weekend shows higher entertainment and leisure engagement

Weekend advertising typically shows:
- Higher consumer engagement for leisure categories
- Lower B2B engagement
- CPMs often lower across many categories
- Purchase intent higher for discretionary spending
- Research and consideration time available

Morning advertising typically shows:
- Higher news and information consumption
- Commute-time mobile engagement
- Lower purchase completion
- Higher CPMs for certain placements
- B2B decision-maker attention

Evening advertising typically shows:
- Higher entertainment consumption
- Family and household decision-making
- Higher purchase completion for e-commerce
- Premium inventory for streaming and CTV
- Relaxation and consideration mindset

8.3 EXPERT DIAGNOSTIC QUESTIONS FOR DAY AND TIME TARGETING

When user discusses dayparting strategy, agent SHOULD ask:
- What does your conversion data show about day and time patterns
- Are there category-specific consideration patterns
- What is budget impact of restricting delivery windows
- How will restricted delivery affect reach and frequency

================================================================================

User scenario: We want to run a 2-week campaign for our product launch.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1: Learning phase consumes 50 percent or more of flight
- Week 2: Limited optimization possible before flight ends
- Post-flight: Insufficient data for accurate performance assessment
- Brand impact: Minimal awareness building in short window
- Recommendation: Consider 4-6 week minimum for measurable impact

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Extend to 4+ weeks if budget allows to complete learning phase
- If 2 weeks required, concentrate budget for maximum reach
- Set realistic expectations for measurement limitations
- Plan immediate follow-on flight to maintain momentum

User scenario: We want to spend 60 percent of budget in the first 2 weeks.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- Week 1-2: Maximum reach and frequency during priority period
- Week 3-4: Limited budget for optimization based on learnings
- Week 5-6: Reduced presence during later flight period
- Creative: Accelerated fatigue risk with concentrated exposure
- Flexibility: Limited ability to respond to performance signals later

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Confirm business reason justifies front-loading
- Expand creative pool to manage accelerated fatigue
- Set frequency caps to prevent over-exposure early
- Establish triggers for pacing adjustment if available

User scenario: We want to launch during Black Friday Cyber Monday period.

Agent MUST communicate this implication chain:
- CPMs: Expect 40-100 percent premium during BFCM week
- Competition: Maximum competitive intensity
- Consumer intent: Highest purchase intent of year
- Measurement: Noise makes attribution challenging
- Creative: Must cut through unprecedented clutter

Agent SHOULD recommend:
- Budget 40-50 percent higher than normal periods for equivalent SOV
- Launch 2-3 weeks before BFCM to build audience before peak
- Creative strategy must differentiate in high-noise environment
- Set realistic efficiency expectations for peak period

================================================================================

- MPA_Implications_Budget_Decisions_v5_5_v5_5.txt - Budget pacing implications
- Analytics_Engine_v5_5.txt - Timing and pacing optimization formulas
- BRAND_PERFORMANCE_FRAMEWORK_v5_5.txt - Awareness decay curves
- MPA_Expert_Lens_Budget_Allocation_v5_5_v5_5.txt - Seasonal allocation patterns

================================================================================

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the timeline
- Articulate learning phase implications
- Explain measurement limitations
- Recommend minimum viable flight length

Example response pattern:
A [X]-week flight creates timeline challenges for optimization and measurement. Learning phase typically consumes the first 1-2 weeks, leaving limited time for performance optimization. Measurement accuracy requires minimum 4-week window for most channels. If [X] weeks is firm, recommend concentrating budget for maximum reach and setting realistic expectations for optimization and attribution. What business constraint drives this timeline?

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the rationale
- Articulate pacing trade-offs
- Explain flexibility implications
- Recommend monitoring approach

Example response pattern:
[Front/back/even] pacing creates specific trade-offs. [Specific implications]. This approach [advantages] but [limitations]. Recommend [frequency management/creative strategy/monitoring approach] to optimize within this pacing. What external factor drives this pacing preference?

Agent MUST:
- Acknowledge the timing
- Articulate competitive and cost implications
- Explain consumer intent patterns
- Recommend preparation approach

Example response pattern:
Launching during [season/event] positions you in [competitive context]. CPMs typically run [X] percent [higher/lower] than off-peak. Consumer intent is [pattern]. To maximize this timing, recommend [preparation steps]. Budget should account for [seasonal factors]. What is your priority between efficiency and share of voice during this period?
